titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI:30. At the Office— A New here before. With an application for a consular appointment forW. Taylor—for his certificate of appointment to Vera-Cruz—to call again to-morrow— At Calhoun’s Office—for Mrs R. Blodget and for T. B. A. junr. At P.U.S. Letter from Poletica— Applications for pardon— Captain Biddle—his sword—his brother the Major—dined at the President’s— Anduaga, and the foreign Ministers— George and Mary Hellen at Mrs T. Monroe’s— Mrs Adams unwell—changed chamber— Finished Stewart’s Elements.

2. VII:Mrs Adams quite ill—confined almost the whole day to her bed— At the Office, Preble came to apply for a Consular appointment at Lima, or Mexico— Recommends R. Gardner, for Palermo— Cazenove about the Hamburg claim of repayment of discriminating duties, between March and November 1819. Question of the President’s authority not decided— R. B. Lee, to apply for an Office of judge in
Florida— W. Taylor came for his certificate as Consular agent at Vera-Crux— It was not ready—promised it on Monday— He goes immediately to the Havanna, and wishes for a passage thence in a public ship—to enquire of P.U.S.— Letters to J. A. Hamilton and Jonn. Russell, Chairman of Comee. of Foreign Relations H.R. Drafts of Answers to Calls for Columbia River and South-American papers— Evening upon Arrears of Accounts— Letter from John Allen— Baltimore— Reading Locke.

3. V:30— Heard Sparks at the Capitol— Job. 14.10. “But man dieth and wasteth away, yea, man giveth up the ghost, and where is he?” An eloquent funeral discourse upon W. Pinkney— Visited H. Clay, at Brown’s Hotel— But there, Baron De Neuville, Talbot and J. B. Thomas. Clay says he is dyspeptical— Call on Crowell at Mrs Queen’s— Met S. L. Southard—call at Mrs Blake’s to enquire of C. A. Rodney, who is very dangerously ill— Received visits from S. Ringgold with a Mr Kennedy—from Hagerstown and then from C. J. Ingersoll— Enquired of his projected work on the Law of Nations— Says he has almost, but not quite given it up— Evening visit from F. C. Gray. George and Mary Hellen, Eve at T. Monroe’s. Mrs Adams continues very ill.

4. VI:30.Coll. R. M. Johnson here— About C. S. Todd and his accounts— Projects for South-America— Judge in Missouri— Says Benton while acting as an arbitrator in his case, wrote slanderous Letters against him to Crawford— J. A. Hamilton here—and afterwards at the Office— His proposed statement to the Florida Commissioners. F. C. Gray came and took leave—going to-morrow— Search for copies of Letters from his father— Theophilus Parsons, came about a claim upon the French Government for a vessel burnt at Sea in 1807. and two other claims— Dr Morse called, and desired an answer upon my election as one of the Vice-Presidents of his new Society for civilizing the Indians— Shewed me the answer of Mr Madison, accepting— Mrs. Adams and Johnson Hellen, came down to dinner— Mr and Mrs. Frye were here after dinner— Evening at R. Cutt’s, with Mary Hellen— Large party. Piano dancing. George went to Major Roberdeau’s at Georgetown—

5. VII—G. Hay here— To solicit advances for T. Watkins— My objections— Watkins himself at the Office— His urgency— My obduracy— R. O’Brien— His remarks upon our fortifications and line of Battle Ships— Columbus, sails badly and steers badly. Franklin and Independence— Lower tier of guns almost under water— At P.U.S. he was not at home— Left papers— looking up papers for the Columbia river call— Archer’s 4 Resolutions presented to H.R— Evening parties at Mrs. W. Cox’s and Miss Tayloe’s— I did not attend either. T. Monroe junr. called at the Office and took leave—

6. VII.D. P. Cook here this morning— Asked me to draw up a Report for him, upon the two Reports from the Treasury department, concerning the examination of the Land-
Offices— I declined; but advised him in disapproving the employment of Thomas to present it in the least unfavourable light— He says that Lacock wrote the Letter in the National Intelligencer, defending the employment of Thomas— Cardell here—occupied about his Academy of Language and Belles-Lettres— Scott of Missouri with Mauri the Italian who comes back with application for a Consular appointment somewhere La Rochelle—Palermo—Venice— At the Office— W. Taylor came twice, gave him his certificate as Consular commercial agent at Vera-Crux—and leave to go in a public ship if one touches at the Havanna— Blair of H.R—applying for discharge of La Costa, a convict for Slave-trading, in prison at Boston. Watkins with a Letter from the Florida Commissioners, about Contract claims— Sanford— Speculations upon N. York politics— B. O. Tyler; with Certificate of Franklin Insurance Company Shares. P.U.S. new draft of Message to go with South-American papers— Poinsett’s advice to say nothing of the chance of a rupture with Spain— Meeting appointed for to-morrow. Archer’s Resolutions— Violent and unjust— Search for Columbia river call papers continued— Walk after dinner with Mrs. Adams, George and Mary Hellen— Bringing up arrears of Waste-Book— Drawing Room, not held— Mrs Monroe ill.

7. VI:30. At the Office— Mr Sanford— His wish to go to France. Told him P.U.S. had otherwise disposed of the Mission—as I believed— Asked him if he would go to Lisbon— He answered doubtingly— Education of his children—doubts of an appropriation— Appeared disappointed— Cabinet Meeting— Wirt only absent. Draft of Message recommending a recognition of South-American Independence— New Modification— No notice of the part Spain may take— Paragraph expressing a doubt of the executive power to recognize— Not to be inserted— Question whether to include Mexico— Calhoun doubts— Best to recognize all at once— Wilcocks’s Letter to be sent with the other papers to H.R.— Opinions unanimous— Search at the Office for papers to be sent to H.R— Walk after dinner with Mrs. Adams and George— Bringing up arrears of Waste-Book.

8. V:15. Note from P.U.S. Cabinet Meeting at 11— Second Note, asking me to call before the Meeting, found H. Nelson with him, who retired. He had made some alteration, in the draft; and said two questions had occurred to him since yesterday—one whether this message should be sent in before my final answer to Anduaga on the complaints against Jackson— The other whether it would not be better to send the Message as confidential, and remind Congress of the critical state of the world; and of our affairs— I thought it best to send the Message now, and to make it public—so all thought at the Meeting, all but Wirt present. Question made
whether to include Mexico—agreed that it should; Calhoun only doubting a little— My Main reason for acting now, and including all, being to take the lead in the recognition— Sent the papers to P.U.S. and he sent the Message in to Congress— Dates of the Declarations of Independence— Gouverneur at the Office. Draft of Answer to the Florida Treaty Claim Commissioners, sent to P.U.S. he sent it back with remarks this Evening— Received the French Standards of Weights and Measures— Evening party at Dr. Worthington’s, Georgetown. George and Mary Hellen went— I did not— Eve, revising Account-Book. Clay here.

9. V:30.D. Brent here. Meade’s Letter with endorsement by P.U.S— Lowndes, with draft of Resolutions concerning weights and Measures. Will write me a Note— Addition to my draft of Answer to Claim Commissioners— At the Office, Cocke, with judge White’sson—of Tennessee— Holmes of Mississippi— His recommendation of Griffith as District Attorney for Mississippi— Young Hillhouse—thanked me for Letters furnished him when he went to France— E. Wyer. His anecdotes about W. Pinkney— His Memory—his Vanity— His comments upon me— Wrote to J. Forsyth— Company to dine— Messrs. King of Alabama, Mills, Waller Taylor, Senators, Thompson Secy of the Navy, Bates, Bigelow, Butler, Edwards of Pennsylvania, Kirkland, Lincoln, Metcalfe, Moore of Virginia, Smith of Maryland, Stoddard, and Walworth of the House and Sanford formed the company. Messrs. Morril and T. H. Williams of the Senate, Baldwin, Blackledge and Vance of the House, and Coll. Polk were invited, but sent excuses or did not come— Evening at the Baron Hyde de Neuville’s— Received from the Spanish Minister Anduaga, a Protest against the President’s Message to Congress, of yesterday, concerning South American Independence—

10. VII: Heard Summerfield, a young Englishman, at the Methodist Church. Romans 8.32. “He that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us all, how shall he not with him also freely give us all things?” An eloquent discourse, premeditated, but extemporaneous— The house was much crowded— I called at the President’s, but he was gone out. Home—day absorbed with the mail and newspapers. Walk before dinner alone, and after with Mrs. Adams— La Croix, Algebra—

11. VI:30.Dr Morse here— Asked again my answer upon my being made one of the Vice Presidents of his Indian civilizing Society— I thought no answer necessary. All the heads of Departments with many others are made ex-office Vice Presidents. As there are some prejudices against the Society, and I was annexed to it without being consulted, I believed it best not to make myself a party to the controversy— He acquiesced— And was enlarging upon the objects and motives of the Society—when MrKoecker came in— A German dentist settled at Philadelphia, but
about removing to England to be cured of dyspepsy— And solicits Letters of recommendation— At the Office— Tracy a claimant upon Spain before the Florida Commissioners came— They admitted this morning contract claims.came with a Mr Griffin from Vermont or New-York— At P.U.S— Told him of the protest from Anduaga— To which he desired me to give a conciliatory reply— He said he heard Poletica, had called the Recognition Message a profligate measure— He was anxious that I should immediately reply to Anduaga’s complaints against Jackson, and communicate the reply to Congress— Said he was told that there were many people in Virginia, he did not know how many, who would countenance Archer’s Resolutions, and if Spain was not answered upon the complaints against Jackson, would attribute to that cause, any act of hostility she might commit under the provocation of this recognition— I thought the answer to Anduaga, ought immediately to be prepared— But doubted the propriety of communicating it to Congress; at least without a Call— Because I knew the object of these cavillers was, to peck at the Answer itself— And as Archer has already more than he can wield, I do not incline to give him a refuge to retreat upon, or a substitute upon which to vent his spleen— The President said this was to be considered— I said I would prepare the draft of an answer, and present it to him for consideration— I told him Jonathan Russell, Chairman of the Committee of foreign Relations, had asked me Saturday at Hyde’s, whether he had proposed to us a tonnage duty of 5 dollars a ton upon the bulk of merchandize, discriminating duty, by a Convention for 18 months—and on my answering no—had asked whether such a proposition would be acceptable? The President said—Hyde must make openly whatever offer he had to propose— I spoke of the question between R. Purdy, Marshal ofTennessee, and his Assistants—told him what had passed on the subject; and advised that his conduct should be examined— He had sent to the Department the complaints made through N. Cannon of the House, and I returned them to him— Began draft to Anduaga— M. L. Hill came in after dinner—distribution of the Secret Journals of Congress to Literary Institutions— Hill says Archer told a Gentleman that he offered his resolutions to make sport— Evening with George, and Mary Hellen, at Coll. W. Coxe’s at Georgetown— Dancing— Miss Ridgley— Genl. Bernard— Lefevre Desnouettes.

12. VII.J. D. Dickinson here, and Sanford— Dickinson to recommend Davis, to be Consul at Gibraltar— Sanford, about his projected mission to France, Portugal, Spain or Mexico— At the Office— Russell, Chairman of the Committee of foreign relations— The recognition Message referred to them: A report to be made— I read to him a translation of Anduaga’s Protest against the Message, and an extract from Forsyth’s despatch of 17. December last relating to the affairs of Ultramar in Spain. I shewed
him Hyde’s Note of 60 pages, received last Saturday, and asked him if he, or the Committee thought we ought to accept a proposal, of a five dollar discriminating tonnage duty—he did not know— There came two Louisianians, named Mercier and Chabord for Passports— General Bernard and Captain Poussin called— Talked of New-Orleans, Pensacola, Tampa Bay, and Cuba— Mr Chevallié came to request an immediate Message to Congress recommending the Beaumarchais claim. Mr R. King of the Senate came— His remarks on the recognition Message— Opportunity for a handsome State paper— Rumours of an intention to sustain the military and naval institutions; and of divisions in the cabinet— I told him there was no division of opinion upon the measure, and gave him the history of its progress— After dinner James Smith Wilcocks brought me a Letter and Packet of Newspapers from Mr Herrera, Secretary of foreign Affairs to the Mexican Empire— Gave some account of the Country— Evening with George at a Ball, at Coll. Henderson’s.

13. VII:Coll. R. M. Johnson was here, about the District judge to be appointed in Missouri— Between Gray— Peck and Stewart— Says P.U.S. told him this morning he was ready to nominate Peck— Barton gives up . . .y, but proposes Stewart as a Mezzo termine. But the Coll. says Peck would be much the best appointment. South-America—who to go? N. Edwards— At the Office—continued draft to Anduaga—without interruption— Dined at Calhoun’s. Judges of Supreme Court. Poletica, Clay, Bibb, Sedgwick, Poinsett, Cambreleng, and Koecker— George went with me— Mrs Adams, Mary and Johnson Hellen were invited but did not go— Evening at a dancing party at Genl. Smith’s at Georgetown— We stopped at home, and took up Mary Hellen— H. G. Otis spoke of Wilcocks. Chess with Coll. Henderson. Home at near Midnight.

14. VII: At the Office— Jonn. Russell, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations. Left a Letter enquiring what appropriations the Executive would wish for South American Missions and hinted that the Committee were for making the largest—that is, for sending Ministers Plenipotentiary to each one of the Southern Republics—to avoid jealousy between them; by treating them all alike— J. S. Wilcocks, came to solicit the appointment of Consul General in Mexico, and is very anxious to be despatched forthwith. Genl. P. B. Porter, called, upon his return from Virginia to his residence in the State of New-York— I went to the President’s, but he had rode out—continued the draft of a Note to Anduaga— Note from him, announcing that he is going to pass some time at Philadelphia— Passionate Note from Hyde de Neuville, about La Pensée— Letter from Judge Johnson concerning Pirates, 8 sentenced to death at Savannah— Evening idle at home.

15. VI.W. R. King here, about his Accounts as Secretary of Legation, at St. Petersburg in 1816. D. P. Cook— His report upon Crawford’s employment of the Senator Thomas— Says the transactions with the broken Banks is much worse— Bulfinch junr here, proposes
proposes to take up N. Read’s Note of May 1820— I could not find it— At the Metropolis Bank— Mrs Adams went to Alexandria. At the Office— Genl. P. B. Porter— About the accounts of the joint Commission, of which he is a member— Says the English Agents in it are more expensive than ours—wishes the charges could be several, and not joint— Eustis— Insinuates, Coll. Abraham Eustis’s application for Office in Florida— Says he was wronged in the new arrangement of the army— That P.U.S. promised he should have any office, he would take in Florida— Not Governor—Not judge—but—Marshal— To be sure, he was the denouncer of Forbes— But then it was before he had any thought of wanting his office— Fuller—only for a few minutes— R. King—Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations of the Senate. Enquiry what appropriations wanted for South-American Missions? To inform him to-morrow— At P.U.S— Case of La Penseè and her Cargo at New-Orleans— Note upon Note from Hyde— To give Judge Johnson’s draft of a Bill, to J. Sergeant, Chairman of the Judiciary Committee of H.R— Left Russell’s Letter, with P.U.S.— He is for indulging them in all their profusion of South American diplomacy— I had some scruples— He will send me directions to-morrow morning— Evening party at Mrs Brown’s of Louisiana. N. Biddle there— Went with Mrs Thornton— George and Mary Hellen—dancing— Hyde’s talk of a Habeas Corpus for the Negroes of La Penseés Cargo, at New-Orleans.

16. VII:30.Thomas, from the Metropolis Bank, with the certificates for Mrs Hellen. At the Office— Gave him a check. Received three Notes from P.U.S—continued the draft to Anduaga— Company to dine— Senators Dickerson, R. King, Southard and Talbot— H.R. Cannon, Conkling, Eddy, Eustis, Hill, Litchfield, Little, Hugh Nelson, Tomlinson and Upham, and Crowell— Knight S.U.S. Abbott, Blair, New, RandolphScott, invited but came not—also Clay who is sick— Evening at Baron de Neuville’s— Their last Evening party— Great crowd—dancing— Chess with General Macomb.

17. VII. Twice at Church. in the Morning, heard Walker at the Capitol. John 14.11. “Believe me, that I am in the Father, and the father in me, or else believe me—for the very work’s sake.” It was a comparative view of the Evidences of Christianity resulting from the miracles, with that arising from the character of Christ: ingenious, but not very solid— Walker is a Unitarian of Charlestown, with a Cambridge delivery— That is, wretched— I called after the morning service on Judge Story, and Mr Sedgwick at Queen’s Hotel— On Mr Koecker at Miss Heyer: the only one whom I saw— On Mr Clay at Brown’s Hotel. He was confined to his bed; and on Mr N. Biddle
at Strother’s— Left Cards— Found Major and Miss Mary Roberdeau at our house— Mr Bailey, Mr Child and his brother afterwards came in— At 3. I went with George to Mr Post’s Church, under the Capitol Hill, where Mr Summerfield was to have preached. The House was so crowded that he could not get in. He preached in the platform fronting the entrance to the Capitol, from 1. Corinthians 1.23. But we preach, Christ crucified— It was upon the atonement— In substance the same sermon, I had heard from him last Sunday Morning— I came home so much fatigued that I wasted the evening in idleness— George fainted there and was brought home by Major Roberdeau.

18. VII:30. Before breakfast, Jonathan Russell came, with the draft of his Report, as Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations, on the Recognition Message, which he gave me to read— It is well drawn, and I found in it only the words “carried perhaps to excess,” applied to the deference of this Government for Spain which has delayed the recognition of the Independence of the South-American Provinces till this time— I objected to them, and after a slight defence of them, he marked them for the consideration of the Committee— He asked for the answer to the questions as to the amount of appropriations, which I afterwards sent him— E. A. Brown S.U.S. came with a Letter from Genl. Lythe. A recommendation of R. Todd, as Consul for Vera-Cruz— I told him the place was filled— H. S. Edwards of Connecticut was here with Johnson, a lawyer of New-York, who brought a budget of papers in defence of A. P. Edwards, against the charges of Jacob Lewis— At the Office, Mr Barber, and Burrows of Connecticut, to enquire what Government could be applied to, for indemnity for the loss of the Hersilia— The robber had no warrant from any Government— Josiah Meigs came and examined the French Metres and Kilogrammes. Mr Rankin made some enquiries as to the Land titles, Claimants under English Grants and Yazoo papers— Wishes for evidence from Records in England; concerning which he will write to me— Poinsett was charged from the City Council of Charleston S.C. to enquire if the Government would build a Court-house for them, for the U.S. Courts to sit in— I told him very readily, if Congress would grant the money. They must petition Congress— Poinsett took his box of tin medals from Philadelphia. Mr March, brother of the Consul at Madeira, called on me—going through the City from the Southward to New-York— Talk about the duties on Madeira wines—extravagant. Mr Tomlinson, brought new recommendations of a Mr Hubbell, as Consul at Manilla— The promised Letter of complaint from Captain Henley has not yet been reviewed— No proof that Steward has left Manilla— Nor of his bad habits— Tomlinson left several Letters— Poletica the Russian Minister, came to explain his having said to Miss Spear that the recognition message was
was a most unprincipled measure— He did say so—but he did not mean it— He did not think so— It was a mere joke—in return for a joke of Miss Spear, who told him the Emperor Alexander was a tyrant— Perhaps it was indiscreet; but he had given his real opinion of the Message to Calhoun— Calhoun had told me of it— Poletica said he was going away and wished to stand well with this Government. His instructions were always to treat it with respect, and such had always been his intentions— I told him I would explain the matter to the President. Wyer came in— Coll. F Pell’s inuendoes of a Letter from one of the Commissioners at Ghent to a Consul in the North of Europe, to be published in about eighteen Months— What was it? I told him it was the Letter of which Harris had hoped to make such hopeful use— Benton’s speech— Garnet’s— The President came in and Wyer withdrew— Several military nominations rejected by the Senate— Cook’s resolutions offered this day in H.R.— New Note from Hyde, about La Pensee, and the Negroes. P.U.S. took it— Coming home to dinner I found Mrs. Clarke, and her child, Susan here— Evening visits from James Greenleaf and James S. Wilcocks— This is a fair sample of one day— How impossible to keep a detailed journal of such?— I had scarce half an hour for continuing the draft to Anduaga.

19. V:30.Coll. R. M. Johnson S.U.S. was here this morning, full of the nominations for the State of Missouri, and for the new Government in Florida— He still recommends Peck for district judge, and Joshua Barton for district Attorney in Missouri— Great and fruitless anxiety for the appointment of Duval as Governor of Florida. But the President has pledged himself to Macon in favour of a Mr Branch late Governor of North-Carolina— Violent debates in Senate on the military nominations— Mr Lowrie S.U.S. from Pennsylvania, with a Mr Mackey from Pittsburgh. Lowrie wanted an authenticated copy of the apportionment Law—to send to the Pennsylvania Legislature— Johnson asked for another— At the Office— Lieutenant Wolfe Tone came to say that he should embark for England in about a fortnight, and wished to be bearer of despatches— Mr Melville, son of the Naval Officer at Boston came— The time of re-appointment for his father has come round; and there are some objections— He says however he shall remove them. Mr. Pedersen the Danish Minister called— Spoke about Mr Levy’s complaints at St. Thomas; and professed his willingness to do what he could to assist him— Spoke with approbation of the recognition Messages though he said his Colleagues here did not think with him— Mr Cazenove came about the Hamburg discriminating duties
nothing concerning it yet done— I called at the President’s— He was not at home, but afterwards sent for me— The Pirates under Sentence of death at Savannah— To reprieve them all— Hyde de Neuvillle and La Pensée— Instructions to the Marshal and District Attorney at New-Orleans— Dauphin Island fortifications— Second Report of Board of Engineers— P.U.S. preparing a Message to Congress recommending them; notwithstanding Report of the Military Committee H.R. against them— Evening party at Kerr’s— George and Mary Hellen went.— I finished this morning the reading of Locke’s Essay. I had not before read it since I was at college; and now that which most struck me upon this perusal was, how much I remembered of the book, and how little I retained of its contents— I mean this—that the principal ideas and doctrines of the book have become by their permanent influence upon my mind so identified with my own Understanding, that I had forgotten whence I had first derived them— We all use Language in this way— That is, in the use of words we annex our ideas to them, which we must have learnt before; but without recollecting when or from where we first derived the knowledge of their meaning.

20. VI.Mr S. Moore, Member of H.R. from Pennsylvania, came to my house, to recommend James S. Wilcocks as Consul General in Mexico— At the Office, there came Mr Johnson of New-York about A. P. Edwards’s affair— I told him I had read the papers and was satisfied— They were now in the hands of P.U.S— He said Mr Edwards was now going to India, which would take the Month— But hoped nevertheless that the President would restore him to the appointment of Consul at Buenos-Ayres— I said the appointment must now be made by Nomination to the Senate, and would perhaps not admit of delay— Seaton came to ask for the printing of the digest to be made of manufactures returned with the Census— He says the paper now yields them no profit— They depend altogether upon the Congress Printing— Talked of J. Randolph, who embarked last Saturday at N. York for London— Went as a Gentleman— Kept T. Monroe junr. up with him one Night till 5.AM. and the next Night a Shoe-black— Mr G. M’Glassin came to solicit the appointment of Marshal in Florida— Genl. Boyd, for that of Naval Officer at Boston— Says Crawford is for a change; and P.U.S. against it—but that it will be submitted to a Cabinet Meeting— Mr R. King S.U.S. came to speak of a Mr de Tubeuf, appointed Consul at Cette, in France; and to ask that his Commission might be sent to him without delay. He also read me a Letter from R. Lenox at New-York, enclosing an extract of one to him from Sir Simon H. Clark, a West-Indian in London, stating the intention of the British Government to open the trade between U.S. and the British West-Indies— He spoke also of the rejection by the Senate of sundry military nominations. He had supported the nominations, but thought the objections against them strong— Eve with George at the drawing-room— Judge P. Smith there— General Harden of Georgia and many other Strangers— L. Harris there— Mrs Hay’s private conversation
interrupted by J. Rhea— He disputes her ordering him away. Mrs Hay’s object was only to enquire how she would send a Letter to the ci-devant Queen of Holland, at Augsburg.

21. VII. A Mr Hezekiah Burhans, author of a Spelling-book, came to ask of me a certificate in favour of his book— I told him I gave no recommendations of books— He left it with me however, in the hope that I would make an exception in favour of its extraordinary merit, and his wish to make it the universal spelling book for the whole Union— He said Webster’s was going quite out of fashion— At the Office, came a Mr William Colesbury, lately from Buenos-Ayres— He brought me a Letter of introduction from J. M. Forbes— He has been residing eight or ten years at Mendoza— He had with him a youth, his nephew— Mr. Plantou the dentist whose wife painted an Allegorical Picture of the Peace of Ghent; which they have been these four years soliciting Congress to buy, brought me some teeth of his own invention, and asked for my influence with members of Congress to prevail on them to buy the picture— Continued the draft to Anduaga— Evening with Mrs Clarke, George and Mary Hellen, at a dancing party at Mr T. Munroe’s.

22. VI.— Finished reading Locke— Began Humboldt’s Nouvelle Espagne. Note from P.U.S— Cabinet Meeting at 1— P.U.S. had a draft of a Message to Congress strongly urging the continuance of the fortifications begun upon Dauphin Island— Report of Military Committee H.R.U.S. against them— Second Report of Engineers BernardTotten and Elliott in their favour— The Message pressed them vehemently upon the house— Crawford took ground as strong against them— Said the second report of the Engineers was a very feeble attempt to support them— That the would never have proposed the fort on Dauphin Island, if the shallowness of the water been known; but that now they are obliged to support it because they formerly recommended it— Calhoun was very anxious for the Message; but it seemed to me, had no solid reply to the Report of the Military Committee— Calhoun and Crawford had a learned discussion upon the Attack and defence of places, by land siege— The question was upon a fort on an Island to defend a channel a mile distant, against the passage of Sloops and Schooners. Crawford contended that in modern warfare, fortifications were nothing. Armies made nothing of leaving them behind them—and very strong places, could be taken in a week— Calhoun gravely disputed these absurdities, and there was much suppressed ill humour in the manner of their debate— Crawford went away, about 1/2— I professed upon the military part of the question to pin my faith upon the Report of the Engineers, and the opinion of the President; but urged prudential Considerations— Congress, and especially H.R. pronounced decidedly against them, last Session— The Military Committee, have reported against them now— What will be result of the Executive’s putting himself
in collision with them— Thompson said it might be the duty of the Executive; to do so—to which I agreed—but was it?— Calhoun admitted there was no military man in the house likely to support the views of the Executive against the Committee. Poinsett and Tattnall, were mentioned as Military men, but no Speakers— Calhoun suggested that the Message should urge the alternative, of continuing the work, or settling the contracts already made— P.U.S. objected that it would be said the argument and the proposal would be inconsistent with each other— I asked, if to the argument there could not be added a conciliatory admission that the work was begun when the shallowness of the Water was not known, and there was a reliance upon the old Charts— Thompson thought it would bring a charge of heedlessness and waste in the undertaking— I thought candour of concession, better than obstinacy in error—especially than counting a conflict upon weak ground— We broke up after 5— Wirt only absent— Mrbrought me a Letter of recommendation from J. Holmes— He applies, for office in Florida— Evening at home writing— Dr Thornton was here, but I did not see him.

23. V:45.E. A. Brown—S.U.S. here, with an application for a person named Hatch, for a Passport to go to Mexico— At the Office— Mr Chevallié, about the claims of the heirs of Beaumarchais— I promised him that a Message concerning it should be sent to Congress next week. Mr. Jonathan Russell, for a Mr Ammidon, and other claimants upon China— He wants a Letter from P.U.S. to the Emperor of China, and if allowable to the Vice-roy at Canton—or if not from P.U.S. to the Vice-roy, then from me— The papers are with P.U.S— Wrote to Captain Biddle— Instructions to demand the Florida Documents of the Governor of Cuba. Took and read the Letter to P.U.S. which he approved—asked if Biddle would expect compensation. I supposed he would— Letter from W. Reed of Marblehead and certificates of interruptions of Newfoundland fishing vessels by French Officers— To enquire— Company to dine— Eaton, Lanman, Otis, Ruggles S.U.S— Van Buren sent an excuse S. C. Allen, Borland, Cushman, Fuller, Garnett, F. Johnson, M’Carty, Ross, Russ, H.R. GorhamKent, Tracy, Trimble, Van Rensselaer, Van Swearingen and Whitman, did not come— Pederson, James Greenleaf, Judge P. Smith of New-York, and J. S. Wilcocks came; H. Clay, Genl. Harden of Georgia, Koecker, Richardson and Sedgwick were invited, and excused— After they were gone, I went into Dr Thornton’s. My family there— Mrs T. Peter and her daughter America— C. King the Painter and a Dr. Hayden. There was music.

24. VI:30. Attended at St. John’s Church, and heard Mr M’Ilvaine. Luke. 16.1. [“]There was a certain rich man, which had a steward; and the same was accused unto him that he had wasted his Goods.” A Charity Sermon, followed by a Collection for the benefit of the female orphan asylum— Very eloquent, occasionally pathetic—but somewhat theatrical— a Voluminous Mail—occupied till 5. in reading the Letters.
Mrs Adams, Mrs Clarke, Mary Hellen and George spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s. I was at home writing.

25. VI:30. A Mr Costen of Baltimore came to my house— He wanted to see the correspondence of Davie, Ellsworth and Murray, with the French Government prior to the Convention of October 1800. He afterwards called at the Office. Note from Gales and Seaton—asking for an advance on the Census fund— Mr Deabbate, Consul General from Sardinia called at the Office— Said he had important propositions to make— To see him again to-morrow— Asked me to introduce him to P.U.S— Received at home a Note from him and enclosures— W. R. King came about his accounts— I am to ask the decision of the President upon them— Mr Bailey introduced to me a young man named Nelson—from Wheeling Virginia— James Greenleaf came to solicit the appointment of Commissioner of the Public Buildings vacated by the Death of Coll. Lane, for Mr Elgar— Evening party at Secretary of the Navy’s— George and Mary Hellen went. I did not.

26. VI.H. S. Edwards member of Congress from Connecticut came to enquire, what had been done in the case of his brother Alfred P. Edwards; I told him the President had the papers. I had been satisfied with the refutation of the charges— If the President was, I would write to his brother a declaration to that effect— But as he was going to India, the appointment to Buenos-Ayres could not be renewed— And any appointment to Buenos-Ayres now, must be as Consul and by nomination to the Senate— He said he did not care a damn for a certificate. His brother had been injured by Mr Monroe, more than any certificate could ever repair— That Mr Monroe had published a book to complain of wrongs to himself, and ought to have known better than to have done the like— He knew that Jacob Lewis was in prison limits under a judgment of Edwards against him, and his pamphlet charges carried absurdity on their face— I defended the proceedings of the President— Edwards said he had no complaint against me—and meant to blame in P.U.S—only his weakness— At P.U.S— Wirt came in and afterwards Thompson Secretary of the Navy— P.U.S said he had determined to send his Message about the Dauphin Island fort—and also a Message to the Senate withdrawing his military nominations; Towson and Gadsden having been rejected— He accordingly sent the Message this day— I mentioned W. R. King’s account, which he said should be approved— Case of the Centinella and La Pensée at New-Orleans— Marshal to be instructed to send them away— Said he would receive Deabbate to-morrow, at 2— Answer to the Call of H.R. enquiring who commands the army U.S. in Florida— Calhoun answers that no orders had been given from the War-Department— I said that would not fully answer the Call—a special statement of the Circumstances should be made. P.U.S. asked me to make it—but could not find the papers— At the Office— Deabbate came— Claims reciprocity for Sardinian vessels. I mentioned the
disadvantages of our vessels in Sardinian Ports which he denied— I read him a passage from Schee’s Letter. He desired I would make a Statement of it in writing— Mr Hyde de Neuville came— Long conference with him, on our commercial negotiation—proposes a discriminating duty of 25 francs per Ton of Merchandize said he had no instructions of later date than 3. January— Pasquier’s last Instructions before he went out of Office were very high-toned—perhaps to shew his Spirit at the last moment. Perhaps, to leave a knot for his Successor— Standing of France— English policy— The Havanna— Slavery in 20 years— France to recover St. Domingo—bluster and fluster— I told him I would mention to P.U.S. his proposal for the 25 frank tonnage duty— He says he wishes to go to New-York—and must go to his other mission— Evening at home— Mrs Adams ill in bed.

27. VI:E. Wyer here— Russell’s remarks upon Unitarians. At the Office. Deabbate came complaint against Schee. At P.U.S— He had rode out— Deabbate returned with me to the Office; waited two hours, and I read the Edinburgh Review of Madame de Stael’s posthumous works— Introduced Deabbate to P.U.S— Finished and took there the draft to Anduaga— Idled off the Evening with the solution of Arithmetical questions— Mrs Adams recovered.

28. VI. At the Office— C. J. Ingersoll— Renominated, as District Attorney for Eastern District of Pennsylvania— Says there are objections against him in Senate—which he has come to explain— Draft of Message on the Beaumarchais claim— Of reply to Poletica— Mr M’Glassin called again— Dined at Captain Chauncey’s with a company of 20. Evening with Mrs Clarke, Mary Hellen and George at Mr Canning’s Ball— Chess with Coll. Wool.

29. VI.T. Fuller here, with Commission and Instructions of D. C. De Forrest as Consul General from the United Provinces of South-America— Commissioned in Feby. 1818 by Pueyrredon— I told him Mr Rivadavia has assured J. M. Forbes that this Commission would be revoked— He spoke also of the case of Melville, Naval Office, at Boston— Said he would call on P.U.S— J. Law here; to recommend his brother E. Law at St. Augustine for Office— At the Office— J. A. Dix Aid de Camp to General Brown, came to solicit the appointment of Secretary of Legation to one of the Missions to South-America. By the contemplated reduction of the army, he expects to be dismissed— Mr Amado the Portuguese Charge d’Affaires, came to inform me that he expected a successor out from Paris, and that a Mr Da Costa, attached to the Legation was now here; and he wished to present him to me— I appointed to-morrow at one to receive him; and also for other business upon which Amado said he wished for a Conference— At the President’s— He was out, but afterwards called at the Office— Returns the draft to Anduaga with amendments— The Missions to South-America— S. Smith wishes for specific appropriations— Anderson the Comptroller called, but I did not see him— W. S. Cardell was here yesterday— His devices.

30. VI:Mr Anderson the Comptroller called this morning, while we were at Breakfast, but did not come in— I called on him at his Office— He said the Register had reported my Account as a Minister abroad unsettled more than three years ago; and he must report it to Congress; and as he believed my claim was good, though he did not feel himself authorised to admit my charge of a full outfit on the Mediation Mission, he wished to add any Note that I should please by way of explanation. I said I must obtain the decision of the President on the question of a full outfit for the Mediation Mission. He said he would wait till Tuesday before making the Report. I reminded him of the proposals I had made to him to refer it to arbitration; or to the opinion of the judges of the Supreme Court; which he recollected— Going to the Office I met General Chandler S.U.S—who had left a Letter at the Office enquiring concerning the accounts of the Marshal of Maine for taking the Census— Mr Holmes the other Senator from Maine came for a subscription to rebuild Bowdoin College. Mr Colden, Member of H.R. from New-York, came for an Exequatur for Baron Lederer, as Consul for the Grand-Duke of Tuscany— Amado Grehon came and introduced Da Costa, as attached to the Portuguese Legation— And the special business on which he wished to speak with me was to express the friendly dispositions of the Cortés of Portugal towards the United States; and also to ask for an answer to the last Letter from the Abbè Correa proposing a joint Commission for trial of captures of Portuguese vessels by South-American privateers— He also desired that Mr da Costa, might have an opportunity of being presented to the President— Lieutenant Wolfe Tone came to say he was to sail next Wednesday for Europe and renewed the offer to take Letters— We had company to dine. N. Edwards, Lowrie and Parrott: Senators, with C. Cutts their Secretary— Burton, Cocke, Dana, Hobart, Jackson, Jones of Va.Montgomery, Nelson of Masstts. Rankin, Rochester, Ruggles, Sawyer, Tucker of Va.Williams of N.C. Wood, and Woodcock— Philip Reed and Warfield accepted but sent this morning excuses for indisposition—

31. VI. Heard Mr Sparks at the Capitol. Acts 19.20. “So mightily grew the word of God and prevailed.” The Sermon was an argument in favour of Christianity from its success. I was not duly attentive to it—my mind being absorbed with worldly concerns. Met Coll. Trumbull there— He afterwards called at my house— It took me, almost the whole day to look up the papers relating to my Accounts— The family spent the Eve at Mr Frye’s— I walked there late in the Evening, but missed them on the way as they were returning.
Day— Rise about 6. Read till 10. Breakfast— Read Newspapers and assort them till Noon or one— At the Office till 5 or 6 dine— Evening abroad, or at home reading and writing— Locke and Humboldt.
